regular-body: At 2:31am, trying to pull my thoughts together on my thesis dissertation proposal. My example species is Branta hutchinsii (Richardson, 1832), and maybe it’s just the 2am talking, but … 1832. 1832. The thing I am studying goes back past the invention of the personal computer, past the breakdown of colonialism, past two world wars, past The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock, past the World’s Columbian Exposition, past the formation of the American Ornithologists’ Union, past the foundation of the University of Colorado (and, indeed, the great state of Colorado), past the American Civil War, past On the Origin of Species, past the Sepoy Mutiny, past The Count of Monte Cristo, even past the A Christmas Carol. In 1832, Lewis Carroll and Gustave Eiffel were born; Johann Wolfgang von Goethe and Georges Cuvier died; Audubon was 47, Rafinesque was 49, and my life is too perfect to imagine. And today it is now December.
